title: (WIP) Scrollytelling demo
text:
Note



This is still a work in progress! I‚Äôm hoping to continue exploring more complex scrollytelling techniques.
Fancy JS libraries like scrollama.js help you track which elements are visible based on scroll so that you can do things to update them.
But the basics of getting elements to stick are just done with one bit of CSS: using position: sticky and then using top/left/right/bottom to define the point (for its parent block) at which the content ‚Äústicks‚Äù.
Let‚Äôs see how that works with some standard Quarto .columns. (I‚Äôve made also made the columns a bit wider with .column-body-outset, ‚Äôcause it looks classy.)

Review
This works great!
Since this is all just CSS and both styles are structured very similarly, you could choose to have both options depending on screen size (so overlay at mobile widths and columns at desktop sizes).
But so far, nothing‚Äôs moving or changing. We‚Äôll need some JavaScript for that.

title: (WIP) Scrollytelling demo
text:
Review
This works nicely!
If you open your browser‚Äôs developer tools (Cmd+Opt+I on a Mac or Ctrl+Alt+I on Windows) and go to the Console pane, you can see it log the responseobject every time one of our event handlers fires (because an element scrolls into or out of view). Those are the console.log functions above.
The response object that we‚Äôre printing shows all the information we get when these event handlers fire.That includes not just the element being targeted, but also its index (TODO - is this its DOM order compared to similarly targeted things?) and the direction ("up" or "down") by which it‚Äôs exiting.
You could theoretically use these event handlers, onStepEnter and onStepExit, to do anything. You could have the boxes being detected be invisible, for example, and just use them as trigger points - the actual thing being modified could be sticky and sitting at the top.

title: Before-and-after image demo
text:
Step 2: Importing the module
Let‚Äôs try it out. JuxtaposeJS is on jsDelivr, so we can just import it! It‚Äôs a little stubborn, but requiring the individual file, rather than just the package name, seems to work (thanks, Observable Module Require Debugger!). It produces an error but seems to work, so I just catch the error and ignore it:

require("https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/juxtaposejs@1.1.6/build/js/juxtapose.min.js")
  .catch(() => null)

title: Before-and-after image demo
Quarto experiments
text:
These experiments are about adding the power of web packages and libraries to your Quarto documents. There‚Äôs a focus on keeping things as Quarto-ish as possible and not ‚Äúpopping the hood‚Äù where we can avoid it.
Experiments include:

modal-dialog: add a popup to your report/blog post/slides
juxtapose: before-and-after images with a slider
vertical-slides: a Revealjs presentation that uses a pre-rendered parallax gradient background and transitions to make it look like you‚Äôre sinking down into the sea
scrollytelling: (WIP) some scrollytelling (and scrollytelling-adjacent) techniques for your Quarto documents, from easier to harder
inject-variable: (WIP) Use vanilla JavaScript to create a variable that can be accessed and updated from Observable JS.

Each of the experiments has a code button, but you can also check out the repo itself on GitHub.
